header.title: MPs demand 'complacent' ministers act to end ageism in the workplace
header.subtitle: SENIOR MPs accused the Government and equality bosses yesterday of complacency in the fight against ageism in the workplace.
header.postText: 'The House of Commons' women and equalities committee said the law against discrimination was not being enforced, adding that ageism was rife '.', 'In July, it warned that the talents of more than a million over-50s were being wasted because employers discriminated against them or did not give them enough flexibility to combine jobs and caring responsibilities.', 'It called on the Government and Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) to take action and said  prejudice, unconscious bias and casual ageism in the workplace were illegal under the 2010 Equality Act.', 'Both the Government and the EHRC said they were committed to protecting older workers.', 'But ministers did not accept some key proposals, including making all state employers and large companies publish details of workers ages.', 'They fear such requirements could place an extra burden on firms.Committee chairman Maria Miller said: Without effective intervention from the Government and EHRC, we cannot see how discriminatory practices against older people in employment, that we know are rife, will be tackled.', 'Complacency about age discrimination has to stop.', 'The Daily Express is campaigning to ensure society treats older people with dignity.'

A friend of mine in his mid-forties spent two years looking for work - and I MEAN looking. He'd be up at seven, beat the streets with an armful of CV's, most every day, wouldn't think twice about walking 10-15 miles. Went on all the recommended `courses', did his stints as unpaid "volunteer" if he didn't volunteer he could get sanctioned and denied his job-seekers' allowance. Finally, he found a placement in a large firm where the manager was actually wanting to recruit a token older person. He was the only applicant over 40 years of age. Within 18 months he'd won their `Employee of the Year' award. He got on with his job attending to the customers, whilst the 20-somethings preferred to chat amongst themselves or mess about with their mobile phones. I also know someone in his mid-20's who fantasises about 170-quid trainers and sports cars. He's never out of bed before 11am. He's had one job interview in the last two months and told the prospective employer what HE should be paid. Two weeks later, he's still waiting for that prospective employer to ring him back...Compare and contrast, as they used to say.
